note_content.Chief Complaint: Recent onset of chest pain and shortness of breath.
note_content.History of Present Illness: Patient reports experiencing sharp chest pain that radiates to the left arm over the past two weeks, especially during physical exercise. Shortness of breath with minimal exertion.
note_content.Past Medical History: Hypertension for 20 years, controlled with medication. No prior history of heart disease.
note_content.Family History: Father had heart disease and died from a myocardial infarction at age 68.
note_content.Social History: Retired teacher, non-smoker, moderate alcohol intake.
note_content.Review of Systems: Patient denies any symptoms of fever, cough, or urinary complaints. Has noticed increased fatigue.
note_content.Vital Signs: Blood pressure 160/90 mmHg, Heart rate 88 bpm, Respiratory rate 19 breaths per minute, Temperature 98.6 F.
note_content.Physical Examination: Mild wheezing on auscultation, no edema, regular heart rhythm with no murmurs.
note_content.Investigations: ECG performed, showing T wave inversions in lateral leads. Advised further evaluation with echocardiogram.
note_content.Differential Diagnosis: Myocardial infarction, aortic dissection, pulmonary embolism.
note_content.Plan: Initiate nitroglycerin as needed for chest pain. Increase dose of current hypertensive medication. Schedule for stress test and follow-up echocardiogram. Consider cardiology referral if conditions worsen.
